articles.title: Yanwan Zhu
articles.contents:
Hi! I’m a third year PhD student in the Department of Cognitive, Linguistic and Psychological Sciences at Brown University. I’m interested in understanding how children and adults represent - or learn to represent - complex meanings in their mind. I’m especially interested in abstract logical expressions (broadly defined) and learnability problems. At Brown, I’m advised by Roman Feiman and affiliated with the BLT lab.
Before coming to Brown, I was an undergraduate studying Linguistics and Statistical & Data Sciences at Smith College. At Smith, I worked with Jill de Villiers on language acquisition and assessment.
My name
IPA: /\(jɛnwan \; ʈʂu\)/
All segments in my first name exist in English
My last name is similar to the first syllable of juice ( /\(ʤuː\)/).

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
Contents
Ongoing
Past projects

Ongoing
Currently, I am working on a project exploring young children’s production and comprehension of sentences containing “if” and “when” and their concepts of (un)certainty.
Past projects
Here are some projects I’ve worked on in the past.
Perception of Mandarin nasal codas by Shanghainese bilinguals
Adults’ and children’s comprehension of Neg-raising (With Jill de Villiers, Lydia Quevedo, Lily Berlstein, and Iris Zhong)
Children’s comprehension of factive verbs and wh-questions
